content: How can I help you today?

I've just been feeling really overwhelmed lately. My wife and I are struggling at home, especially with our son having some behavioral problems. It's affecting everything—our marriage, my work, and even my ability to enjoy anything right now. I’m not sure how to fix it all, but I feel like things are falling apart.

That sounds like a heavy load to carry, with so much happening at once. It's understandable that feeling overwhelmed would affect so many areas of your life. You care deeply about your family and your marriage, and it sounds like you’re doing your best to navigate all of this, even though it feels really hard at the moment. What feels like the biggest challenge for you right now?

I think the biggest challenge right now is figuring out how to help my son. His behavior is so out of control sometimes, and my wife and I don’t know what we’re doing wrong or how to make things better. It’s putting so much strain on us, and I feel like I’m failing as a father and a husband.

It’s clear how much you care about your son and your family, and feeling unsure of how to help can leave you questioning yourself. You want to do the right thing for him and for your marriage, but it’s hard to feel confident when things seem unpredictable or overwhelming. What’s been the most difficult part about handling your son’s behavior so far?

The hardest part is feeling like nothing we try seems to work. My wife and I have tried talking to him calmly, setting rules, taking things away, but he still acts out. It's frustrating and I feel like we’re just failing him, and I hate seeing the toll it’s taking on my wife too.

It sounds frustrating and painful to try so many approaches without seeing the changes you're hoping for. It’s completely valid to feel that way when your efforts come up short, especially when you’re watching the emotional impact it has on your wife and family. You clearly want what's best for your son and your family. What keeps you going in trying to find solutions, even when it feels so discouraging?

I guess what keeps me going is knowing that I can’t give up on my son or my family. I want him to have a better experience, to be happy, and to feel loved. And even though it’s exhausting, I want to be the dad he needs and to make things right with my wife. I just don’t know how to do that right now.

Your commitment to your son and your family shines through, even in the midst of the challenges. Wanting your son to feel loved and supported, and striving to repair and strengthen your marriage, shows the deep care you have for them. It’s clear that you’re doing everything you can right now, even though you don’t have all the answers. What are your hopes for the future—what would things look like if they started to improve?

I guess my hope is that my son feels more calm and understood, and that my wife and I can be on the same page about how to support him. I just want some of the tension in our home to ease so we can feel like a family again. It feels like things have been so heavy for so long, and I’d love to feel like we’re all connected and happy.

That vision of connection and happiness for your family is so meaningful. It shows how deeply you value peace and understanding in your home, and how important it is for you to work together with your wife to support your son. Even amidst the weight you’re carrying now, you still hold onto hope for a better future. What steps, small or big, do you think could bring your family closer to that vision?

Maybe starting with small, manageable steps, like finding ways to spend a little more quality time with my wife and daughter, might help. For my son, I think we might need extra help—maybe talking to someone like a specialist or counselor who knows about kids with behavioral challenges. It’s hard to know where to begin, though, and that’s part of why I feel stuck.

Starting with small, intentional steps sounds like a thoughtful approach, especially when things feel overwhelming. Spending quality time with your wife and daughter could help strengthen those connections and ease some tension. Reaching out to a specialist or counselor for support with your son’s behavior also shows your willingness to seek guidance when needed—it could be a helpful resource for both him and your family. Would it feel helpful to explore more about how to take those steps? Or is there anything else you’d like to talk about first?

Yeah, I think exploring those steps could be helpful. I feel like I'm kind of in limbo, not knowing exactly where to start. If you have any ideas or advice about how to find the right kind of help for my son—or even ways to start rebuilding things with my wife and daughter—I’d really appreciate it. I just want to move forward somehow.

It’s encouraging to hear that you want to move forward and are open to exploring steps for positive change. Finding support for your son might begin with looking into specialists who work with children and families—such as counselors or therapists trained in behavioral challenges—to guide you and your wife. As for rebuilding with your wife and daughter, even small gestures like sharing open conversations or scheduling family time could help strengthen those bonds bit by bit.  

Before discussing more details, would it be okay to briefly revisit what you've shared and the hopes you've expressed? Making sure we're on the same page may give clarity as we look ahead. Would that be helpful?
